content.description: Fun route to the right of Roktoberfest in the Government Bay area.  Route starts with a wonderful undercling and works its way up with lots of good side pulls and underclings the entire way up.  The crux is near the second bolt from the top, but with some balance maneuvers is not a problem.  Finish to an easy slab.  Good hands and feet for most of the route, and a spectacular view from the top.
content.protection: Bolts the whole way up to bolted anchors at the top. Anchors on top have steel biners for quickly finishing and descending the route. Standard should be to clip in and lower off instead of rapping. If going to set this as a TR put up draws to the bolts to minimize wear on the fixed gear. 6 Draws minimum required for this route.
content.location: This is the farthest route from the water (Pineapple Jazz).  Start right under the first bolt. Probably possible to walk off the top, but it would be a long walk. Best to lower of the anchors up top.  Route cleaned and bolted by Sean Foster - big thank you to Sean!

content.description:
Named for a waitress from Nelson's Resort whose hairstyle sometimes made her head look like a pineapple and her little dog too! (Princess Jasmine aka Jazz Town aka Jazzy aka Jazz) 

  This is the best 5.7 around. Nice easy climbing to the last bolt and then a bold 5.7 move to the chains. The jugs are there, but it feels exposed at the end. 

  Many of the Nelson's Resort crew TR'd this in their regular shoes in the fall of 2015. Makes a great warm-up climb or intro climb for a noob.
content.location: Leftmost route before shoreline disappears into lake. Bolts are black.

content.description: Bouldery start leads into crimps and pockets and jugs. At the ledge, the climb turns into a layback dihedral to a small roof. Fun, fun, fun!
content.protection: Bolts, anchors. Slight run out between 4th and 5th bolt as route turns into 5.7/8 moves through a ledge. Shouldn't be a problem for a 5.10 leader, but you can bring small pro and a long draw or runner to protect the ledge if you want.
content.location: Right side of Government Bay just before shoreline fades into the lake.

content.description: First route attempted at Government Bay. This short trad line is overhanging and very stout!
content.protection: One wide piece for the start. Standard rack.
content.location: Far left side of Government Bay. Rap down from top onto large rock in water or boat to the wall.

content.description:
Absolute classic!  

  This route defined the second month of my stay in Crane Lake in 2015. While trying to recover some gear I left on Papaya?Banana!, I began to see holds in this angled line to my right. The undercling at the final roof drew me in and the rest of it never let go. 

  Start on the shelf beyond the large detached rock at the left side of Government Bay wall. Do a traverse to a side pull to some crimps under a roof. Pull the roof and immediately mantle to a great resting stance. Then, game on. Boulder left on some sloping crimps to a jug, then push on through the finish.  

  A+ route.
content.location: Left side of Government Bay wall. Boat to the detached rock or hike in from Nelson's Resort and rap to it.

content.description:
Government Bay in Crane Lake holds a great wall with potential for a dozen or so routes.  

  For the past few years, I've zipped past this tiny wall just gazing around at the beautiful lake while Jeff Engel boated me into Canada. Then one day in the summer of 2015, I swam to this wall from the campsite at Picnic Beach and realized how wonderful it could be. 

  A canoe ride with some trad gear led to the discovery of Papaya?Banana! and spending time hanging on that route led to the discovery of the gem, Blueberry Fortress.
